title: Juliette Lewis conquered Hollywood by 22. She‚Äôs finally back on top.
raw_text:
Style Juliette Lewis conquered Hollywood by 22. She‚Äôs finally back on top. The actress‚Äôs offbeat career has culminated in ‚ÄúYellowjackets,‚Äù which is returning for its highly-anticipated second season ‚ÄúI try to stretch myself all the time when possible,‚Äù Juliette Lewis says of her role in ‚ÄúYellowjackets.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not unlike life.‚Äù (Emily Monforte/For The Washington Post)

Listen 10 min Comment on this story Comment Gift Article Share

WESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif. ‚Äî Juliette Lewis‚Äôs early years transpired at breakneck velocity. She worked with Martin Scorsese and Oliver Stone, scored an Oscar nomination, dated Brad Pitt and kicked a drug addiction, all before age 22. She‚Äôs never been inclined to follow a straight trajectory. So, in 2003, Lewis embarked on a six-year sabbatical from acting to pursue music, her band Juliette and the Licks, opening for the Pretenders and Cat Power. ‚ÄúI went for broke,‚Äù says Lewis, which also describes her performances. ‚ÄúWhen I was on the road, I was flying economy, roughing it like a rock and roller, sleeping on a bunk, traveling on a bus.‚Äù

When she returned to acting, the industry had largely forgotten her. It tends to do that. Even with Juliette Lewis, indelible in Scorsese‚Äôs ‚ÄúCape Fear‚Äù (opposite Robert De Niro), Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄúNatural Born Killers‚Äù and Lasse Hallstr√∂m‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Eating Gilbert Grape.‚Äù On a bus, out of mind.

But Lewis is a trouper, nobody‚Äôs snob. She took the long way back, accepting what came her way: sixth-on-the-call-sheet roles, best friend parts, fleeting sitcom appearances, Old Navy ads as a ‚ÄúNational Lampoon‚Äù Audrey Griswold. (There are three: Lewis was ‚ÄúChristmas Vacation‚Äôs‚Äù Audrey in 1989.)

Now, at 49, she sits ‚Äî as much as the kinetic Lewis sits ‚Äî in a Four Seasons suite, no more bus life for her, as a star of Showtime‚Äôs addictive, buzzy ‚ÄúYellowjackets.‚Äù Last season ended with Lewis‚Äôs five-times-in-rehab character Natalie suicidal and ‚Äî spoiler alert! ‚Äî holed up in a motel room until she was abducted. Lewis‚Äôs role is a gift, among the best of her career. The second season began streaming Friday.

‚Äú2022 Was the Year of Juliette Lewis‚Äù declared IndieWire, and it has a point. She appeared in three television series: as ‚Äúprogressive, sensitive mom‚Äù Judy, as she put it, in ‚ÄúQueer as Folk‚Äù; big-haired ‚Äúwild card with a lust for life‚Äù fan-turned-costume-designer Denise in ‚ÄúWelcome to Chippendale‚Äôs‚Äù; and, above all, as Natalie on ‚ÄúYellowjackets.‚Äù

The first two series were limited, one and done, but Lewis will play Natalie for at least a third season and what the producers hope will be five, the longest acting assignment of her career.

‚ÄúMovies are my jam. They‚Äôre my DNA,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI knew how good the writing was on the show but the drawback was that I‚Äôm a commitment-phobe. I was scared of the long-term contract of it. You‚Äôre giving up a certain freedom of time.‚Äù

But she was attracted to the show‚Äôs ambition and the role‚Äôs depth. ‚ÄúI always want to try to do things that make me feel scared or go the distance,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúNatalie has that range and specificity. You‚Äôre sort of in competition with yourself. You don‚Äôt want to repeat. You don‚Äôt want to have gimmicks. I try to stretch myself all the time when possible. It‚Äôs not unlike life.‚Äù

Attired in a jean jacket, red leggings and electric blue sneakers, Lewis erupts in fireworks of thoughts. The linear eludes her. Sentences tend to perambulate only to land in fresh territory.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Valley Girl,‚Äù she says, though she seems nothing of the sort, the daughter of graphic designer Glenis Duggan Batley and the late character actor Geoffrey Lewis. She was raised in nearby Tarzana as a Scientologist, which she has ceased to discuss publicly. Today, she describes herself as ‚Äúa spiritualist.‚Äù

For the uninitiated, ‚ÄúYellowjackets‚Äù is a female ‚ÄúLord of the Flies‚Äù crossed with ‚ÄúLost,‚Äù but also entirely its own thing. It is macabre, moving, surprisingly funny, punctuated with holy-cow, clutch-your-seat moments, and utterly convincing in dramatizing that few things are more frightening than a pack of empowered teenage girls. The series jumps between 1996, when a champion soccer team is marooned in the Canadian wilderness after a plane crash, and present-day New Jersey, as the grown women struggle with the secrets and trauma from their time in the woods.

The adult cast features a trio of gifted, unconventional actresses who first electrified audiences in the Nineties: Lewis, Melanie Lynskey and Christina Ricci. Observing them perform as an ensemble, it‚Äôs a wonder no one thought to cast them together before now.

‚ÄúI watched Christina and Melanie back then thinking, ‚ÄòOh, there‚Äôs another odd one, a rare one,‚Äô which I mean as a compliment,‚Äù Lewis says. ‚ÄúI love seeing people doing what you don‚Äôt expect. We all work very similarly.‚Äù She also refers to herself as ‚Äúmiddle aged‚Äù and ‚Äúa veteran,‚Äù which sounds impossible to anyone with robust memories of watching Lewis as a teenager in ‚ÄúCape Fear.‚Äù Somehow that was 32 years ago. Lewis describes working with Scorsese and Stone ‚Äúas my graduate school. Those directors were my teachers.‚Äù

As Natalie, Lewis appears in a permanent state of distress and devoid of vanity: rumpled attire, uncombed tresses, melted mascara. ‚ÄúThe notion of the stormy waters right at the surface of the character, probably for better or for worse for Juliette, that‚Äôs something she immediately empathized with,‚Äù says ‚ÄúYellowjackets‚Äù director and executive producer Karyn Kusama. ‚ÄúBy the end of the second season, we‚Äôre going to have much more insights into the many tragedies of Natalie, how the weight of the past informs the adult character.‚Äù

For all her character‚Äôs pain, Lewis says, ‚ÄúI feel like Natalie‚Äôs the sanest of all of them. I feel like this is how a very broken human being would express herself. If you like some tragedy with your comedy, Natalie will give it to you.‚Äù

Lynskey, who stars as Shauna, the Jersey housewife with breathtaking knife skills and myriad secrets, says that ‚Äúworking with Juliette, you‚Äôre transported. It‚Äôs just crazy what she can do.‚Äù Filming a scene this season, ‚ÄúJuliette was so delicate and wounded and interesting. When they said ‚Äòcut,‚Äô it was sort of embarrassing because I was crying a little bit and I was definitely not supposed to be crying. I looked over and so was Lauren Ambrose,‚Äù the ‚ÄúSix Feet Under‚Äù actress who joins the cast as adult Van.

On set, Lewis has been known to say before an arduous scene, which describes almost all of them, ‚ÄúI hope the angels show up.‚Äù Lynskey says, ‚ÄúIt really does feel like she‚Äôs channeling something.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are moments when Juliette‚Äôs on screen and she walks through a room where I‚Äôve never seen someone carve space like that,‚Äù says Jonathan Lisco, the series‚Äô showrunner along with creators Ashley Lyle and Bart Nickerson. ‚ÄúShe has an absolute lack of self-consciousness. This season is going to be an up-and-down ride for Natalie. The challenge is for her survival over her demons. Despite what they went through in the woods, all the women have a dynamic longing for that time, that they never felt more.‚Äù Among the producers and writers, Lisco says, Natalie is known as ‚Äúthe hunter.‚Äù She demonstrates mad firearm skills.

‚ÄúNatalie vacillates between explosive rage ‚Äî though she would never hurt you ‚Äî and then she‚Äôs a puddle of sorrow, guilt and shame,‚Äù Lewis says. ‚ÄúI just think the showrunners like seeing me angry. It‚Äôs exhausting. I exhaust myself. She‚Äôs not emoting a lot of lightness or happiness or laughter.‚Äù In two seasons, each requiring five-month shoots near Vancouver, ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs only one scene where I laugh, where she‚Äôs having a good time for a minute.‚Äù

Lewis compares her often-comic scenes with Ricci, who plays semi-sociopathic Misty, to Bette Davis and Joan Crawford in ‚ÄúWhat Ever Happened to Baby Jane?‚Äù though ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to say who is Joan and who is Bette.‚Äù

She was delighted for the variety in doing three recent television series, to be in demand, ‚Äúbut that‚Äôs not something I think I‚Äôll ever do again.‚Äù Her roles in ‚ÄúWelcome to Chippendales‚Äù and ‚ÄúQueer as Folk‚Äù she described as much lighter, a pleasure while ‚ÄúNatalie is scraping the bottom of the barrel.‚Äù

Tate Taylor directed Lewis in ‚ÄúMa,‚Äù ‚ÄúBreaking News in Yuba County‚Äù and three episodes on Fox‚Äôs ‚ÄúFilthy Rich.‚Äù He wanted to cast her in his hit, ‚ÄúThe Help,‚Äù but Lewis was unavailable. (Which part? ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not telling,‚Äù Taylor says.) ‚ÄúShe is a very energetic actress, a very visceral actress with lots of movement. No part is too small,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI think she is one of the underutilized talents in our business. She needs to be in everything.‚Äù

Away from set, Lewis deviates from any script. She‚Äôs the recovering rock and roller who‚Äôs happiest at her rural Southern California home with her dogs, on the hunt for a bureau for her bedroom. Married to skateboarder and entrepreneur Steve Berra from 1999 to 2003, Lewis is single, a devoted aunt. She‚Äôs the proud owner of a souped-up Dodge Challenger, not unlike the one she and Woody Harrelson drive in ‚ÄúNatural Born Killers.‚Äù She once rescued a horse from ‚Äúa life of being in the movies,‚Äù after filming one with the animal in Spain and Mexico. ‚ÄúI paid a whole lot of money to get the horse into the country. Then it turned out the horse was completely unrideable.‚Äù So she had the horse retired to a farm for injured animals. ‚ÄúIt was very symbolic.‚Äù

Lynskey recalled sitting with Lewis last year at the Hollywood Critics Association Awards, where both were nominated for best actress in a dramatic series. (Lynskey won.) Lewis began to worry about how late the event would run, telling her incredulous castmate she had a date afterward. ‚ÄúFor most people, that would have been their entire night,‚Äù Lynskey says.

During the break between ‚ÄúYellowjackets‚Äù seasons two and three, Lewis is filming ‚ÄúThe Thicket‚Äù in Calgary. It‚Äôs a dark western thriller with Peter Dinklage. She plays a violent killer named Cut Throat Bill. Yes, Bill. says Lewis, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll look slightly unrecognizable.‚Äù

After a role like Natalie, ‚ÄúI would like to play a nice, nuanced aristocrat,‚Äù she says. Hard to imagine. ‚ÄúSo, maybe not. Maybe a jazz singer.‚Äù She‚Äôs writing a movie, ‚Äúan exaggeration of themes of things I went through. It‚Äôs loosely, loosely autobiographical,‚Äù and she wants to direct. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll probably produce stuff. I love storytelling. I want to pitch a TV show, that I won‚Äôt be in, about the early punk scene.‚Äù She‚Äôs interested in ‚Äúways to tell stories where I‚Äôm not in front of the camera.‚Äù

Oh, and she wants to make essential oils. Seriously. Lewis adores essential oils.

‚ÄúJuliette has such a truly specific and unique take on the world,‚Äù Kusama says. ‚ÄúThere are times when she just cracked me up with her curiosity and openness.‚Äù

Lewis understands the business. ‚ÄúYou can always work. You can always get bad work,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBut I have a name now,‚Äù meaning she‚Äôs matching the performances and roles of her first burst of work three decades ago.

It was never a straight line. For Lewis, that would never make any sense. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve carved out this funny, funky path I call my own,‚Äù she says. And no one is forgetting her now.

title: U.S. pair of Chock and Bates win first world ice dance title
raw_text:
SAITAMA, Japan ‚Äî Madison Chock and Evan Bates of the United States won their first ice dance title at the figure skating world championships on Saturday.

First after the rhythm dance, Chock and Bates finished first in the free dance at Saitama Super Arena with 134.07 points for a total of 226.1.

Reigning European champions Charlene Guignard and Marco Fabbri of Italy were second with 219.85 points while Grand Prix Final Champions Piper Gilles and Paul Poirier of Canada were third with 217.88.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been pursuing this goal for so many years,‚Äù Bates said. ‚ÄúIt was exciting and stressful all at the same time. I know that the ice dance field is so competitive. We‚Äôve competed against all these teams for so many years. We really just wanted to focus on ourselves and skate our best.‚Äù

Chock and Bates, the three-time Four Continents champions , have been together for 12 years.

They won the silver medal at the 2015 world championships in Beijing, bronze in Boston in 2016 and bronze last year in Montpellier, France.

PHOTOS: US pair of Chock and Bates win first world ice dance title

They have also competed at six Grand Prix Finals, winning four medals - all silver.

raw_text:

Yellowjackets (Showtime at 9) Season 2.

Barrett-Jackson: Revved Up (FYI at 10) Season 9.
